rightAnswer.description: You actually can’t increase network throughput with multiple interfaces, making B false. All three other options are legitimate reasons to attach multiple interfaces to an instance.

asking: Which of the following can you not do with regard to network interfaces?

answerOption.description: Detach a secondary interface from an instance.
Attach an elastic network interface to an instance with an existing interface.
Detach a primary interface from an instance.
Attach an elastic network interface to a different instance than originally attached.

rightAnswer.description: An instance’s primary network interface cannot be detached (C), making that the correct answer. You can detach secondary interfaces (A), attach multiple interfaces (B), and move network interfaces (D).

asking: Which of the following is not a valid attribute for an elastic network interface?

rightAnswer.description: Elastic network interfaces do not have routing tables, but they do have (or can have) IPv4 and IPv6 addresses and a source/destination check flag.

asking: Why might you use an elastic IP address?

answerOption.description: You need an IPv4 address for a specific instance.
You need an IPv6 address for a specific instance.
You want to mask the failure of an instance to network clients.
You want to avoid making changes to your security groups.

rightAnswer.description: Elastic IP addresses are specifically for avoiding being tied to a specific instance, so A and B are not correct. Security groups are typically not associated with a specific IP address (D). This leaves C, a valid reason for an elastic IP address: It can move from one instance (if the instance fails) to another.

asking: Which of the following can you not do with an elastic IP address?

answerOption.description: Change the IP address associated with it while it is in use.
Move it from one instance to another.
Associate it with a single instance in a VPC.

rightAnswer.description: Elastic IP addresses are, by definition, an IP address that will not change, so A is correct—you cannot change the IP address while it is in use. You can move elastic IPs (B), including across VPCs (C), and you absolutely would associate it with a single instance (D).

asking: Which of the following are advantages of an elastic IP? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Reduces the number of IP addresses your VPC uses
Provides protection in case of an instance failure
Allows all attributes of a network interface to be moved at one time
Provides multiple IP addresses for a single instance

rightAnswer.description: An elastic IP can mask the failure of an instance (B) by moving traffic to another running instance transparently. It also allows all the network interface attributes to be moved at one time (C).

asking: Which of the following would you need to do to create an elastic IP address?  (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Allocate an elastic IP address for use in a VPC.
Allocate an IP address in Route 53.
Detach the primary network interface on an instance.
Associate the elastic IP to an instance in your VPC.

rightAnswer.description: To use an elastic IP, you must first allocate it for use in a VPC and then associate it with an instance in that VPC (A and D). Route 53 is not involved at this stage, and you cannot detach the primary network interface on an instance.

asking: Which of these is not a valid means of working with an Amazon EBS snapshot?

rightAnswer.description: There is not such thing as an “EBS management tool” separate from the AWS API, CLI, and console.

asking: Where are individual instances provisioned?

rightAnswer.description: Although instances exist in a region and VPC, and can be part of an Auto Scaling group, they are provisioned into specific availability zones (C).

asking: How are EBS snapshots backed up to S3?

answerOption.description: In full, every time they are changed
EBS snapshots are backed up to RDS.

rightAnswer.description: EBS snapshots are backed up to S3 incrementally.

asking: You have an existing IAM role in use by several instances in your VPC. You make a change in the role, removing permissions to access S3. When does this change take effect on the instances already attached to the role?

answerOption.description: The next time the instances are restarted
The instances preserve the pre-change permissions indefinitely.

rightAnswer.description: Changes to IAM roles take place immediately.

asking: How many IAM roles can you attach to a single instance?

answerOption.description: None, roles are not assigned to instances.

rightAnswer.description: You can only assign a single role to an instance.

asking: How can you attach multiple IAM roles to a single instance? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: You can attach as many roles as you want to an instance.
You cannot, but you can combine the policies each role uses into a single new role and assign that.
You can assign two IAM roles to an instance, but no more than that.
You cannot; only one role can be assigned to an instance.

rightAnswer.description: You can only assign a single role to an instance (D), but you can also create a new role that combines the desired policies (B).

asking: You need to make a change to a role attached to a running instance. What do you need to do to ensure the least amount of downtime? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Update the IAM role via the console or AWS API or CLI.
Re-attach the updated role to the instance.
Other than updating the role, no additional changes are needed.

rightAnswer.description: You always need to make the actual role changes (A). There are then no more actions required for these changes to take effect on the instances.

asking: You have a new set of permissions that you want to attach to a running instance. What do you need to do to ensure the least amount of downtime? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Remove the instance’s IAM role via the console or AWS API or CLI.
Create a new IAM role with the desired permissions.
Stop the instance, assign the role, and restart the instance.
Attach the new role to the running instance.

rightAnswer.description: You’ll first need to create an IAM role with the desired permissions (B). Then, you can attach the role to a running instance to avoid downtime completely (D). Note that this is relatively new; older versions of AWS required restarting the instance.

asking: How can you delete a snapshot of an EBS volume when it’s used as the root device of a registered AMI?

answerOption.description: You can, but only using the AWS API or CLI.
Delete the snapshot using the AWS console.
Ensure that you have correct IAM privileges and delete the AMI.

rightAnswer.description: If a snapshot is the root device of a registered AMI, it cannot be deleted.

asking: Which of these is the best option for encrypting data at rest on an EBS volume?

answerOption.description: Configure the volume’s encryption at creation time.
Configure AES 256 encryption on the volume once it’s been started.
Configure encryption using the OS tools on the attached EC2 instance.
Back up the data in the volume to an encrypted S3 bucket.

rightAnswer.description: Encryption can only be applied to EBS volumes at creation time, so A is correct.

asking: How can you ensure that an EBS root volume persists beyond the life of an EC2 instance, in the event that the instance is terminated?

answerOption.description: Configure the EC2 instance to not terminate its root volume and the EBS volume to persist.
You cannot; root volumes always are deleted when the attached EC2 instance is  terminated.
Ensure that encryption is enabled on the volume and it will automatically persist.

rightAnswer.description: By default, root volumes do get deleted when the associated instance terminates. However, you can configure this to not be the case using the AWS console or CLI (B).

asking: Which of the following is not part of the well-architected framework?

rightAnswer.description: Using defaults is not part of the well-architected framework, and it often is not the most secure approach.

asking: Which of the following should you attempt to automate, according to the AWS well- architected framework? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: The well-architected framework recommends automating security best practices and responses to security events.

asking: Which of the following statements are true? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: You are responsible for security in the cloud.
AWS is responsible for security of the cloud.
AWS is responsible for security in the cloud.
You are responsible for security of the cloud.

rightAnswer.description: AWS is responsible for securing the cloud itself, and then you as a customer are responsible for securing your resources and data in the cloud.

asking: For which of the following is AWS responsible for security? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: AWS is responsible for securing the cloud itself, which means anything that is infrastructure, such as edge locations and availability zones.

asking: For which of the following is AWS not responsible for security?

rightAnswer.description: AWS is responsible for networks, but not the actual traffic across those networks (D).

asking: For which of the following are you not responsible for security?

rightAnswer.description: AWS manages DynamoDB as a managed service. All the other options are your responsibility as a customer of AWS.

asking: Which of the following is not included in the well-architected framework’s definition of security?

rightAnswer.description: The well-architected framework includes four areas for security in the cloud: data protection, infrastructure protection, privilege management, and defective controls.

asking: Which of the following is a principle of the well-architected framework’s security section?

answerOption.description: Encrypt the least amount of data possible.
Always encrypt the most important data.

rightAnswer.description: The well-architected framework suggests encrypting everything where possible, whether it is at rest or in transit.

asking: Which of the following are principles of the well-architected framework’s security sec-tion? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Encrypt data in groups rather than individually.

rightAnswer.description: The well-architected framework suggests encrypting everything where possible, whether the data is at rest or in transit.

asking: Who is responsible for encrypting data in the cloud?

answerOption.description: AWS provides mechanisms such as key rotation for which they are responsible, but you are responsible for appropriate usage of those mechanisms.
AWS provides an API, but you are responsible for security when using that API.

rightAnswer.description: While you are ultimately responsible for the security of your data, AWS provides and accepts responsibility for tools to enable security.

asking: What is the term used to represent the resiliency of data stored in S3?

rightAnswer.description: S3 durability is 99.999999999%, which is often called “11 9s” (or sometimes  “11 nines”) of durability.

asking: Which of these statements is not true?

answerOption.description: AWS recommends encrypting data at rest and in transit.
AWS will never move data between regions unless initiated by the customer.
AWS will initiate moving data between regions if needed.
Customers move data between regions rather than AWS.

rightAnswer.description: AWS will never initiate the movement of data between regions. Content in a region must be moved by the customer or moved in response to a customer action.

asking: Which of the following can be part of a strategy to avoid accidental data overwriting of S3 data?

rightAnswer.description: S3 data can be protected via MFA Delete and versioning, both of which provide a layer of protection against accidental deletes. Additionally, IAM roles can ensure that only those who should be able to delete data can delete data.

asking: Which of the following should always be done to protect your AWS environment?  (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Enable MFA on the root account.
Enable MFA Delete on your S3 buckets.
Set a password rotation policy for users.
Create custom IAM roles for all users.

rightAnswer.description: All of these options are valid, but only two should be done for all environments: enabling MFA on the root account and setting a password rotation policy. Enabling MFA Delete on S3 is a good idea but may not apply to all situations. Further, not all users may need an IAM role; some, for example, are fine with the default roles.

asking: At what level does infrastructure protection exist in AWS?

rightAnswer.description: AWS infrastructure operates at the VPC layer and is almost entirely virtual.

asking: Which of the following might be used to detect or identify a security breach in AWS? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: CloudWatch and CloudTrail both provide monitoring and logging, both of which can identify security breaches. CloudFormation is a deployment mechanism, and Trusted Advisor can identify potential holes, but not actual breaches.

asking: Which of the following AWS services is associated with privilege management?

rightAnswer.description: IAM provides access management through users, roles, and permissions, all of which are related to privileges.

asking: Which of the following AWS services is associated with privilege management?

rightAnswer.description: MFA is Multi-Factor Authentication, which adds a layer of protection related to privilege management.

asking: Which of the following AWS services is associated with identifying potential security holes?

rightAnswer.description: Trusted Advisor is AWS’s service for looking at your system and finding standard “holes” in your infrastructure that might allow for security breaches and then to suggest remediation.

asking: Which of the following is not one of the five pillars in the cloud defined by the AWS well-architected framework?

rightAnswer.description: AWS’s well-architected framework provides for five pillars: operational excellence, security, reliability, performance efficiency, and cost optimization. Organizational issues are considered outside of this framework (C).

asking: Which of the following is not one of the five pillars in the cloud defined by the AWS well-architected framework?

rightAnswer.description: AWS’s well-architected framework provides for five pillars: operational excellence, security, reliability, performance efficiency, and cost optimization. Usability is not a key concern of the cloud (B), although it is important for applications hosted within the cloud.

asking: Which of the following is not one of the security principles recommended by AWS’s well-architected framework?

answerOption.description: Apply security at the highest layers.
Protect data in transit and at rest.

rightAnswer.description: C is a misstatement of the correct principle; apply security at all layers. Security should be present at all layers, not just at the highest layers.

asking: Which of the following is one of the security principles recommended by AWS’s well-architected framework?

answerOption.description: Make sure all users have passwords.
Turn on MFA Delete for S3 buckets.

rightAnswer.description: While A and C are both good ideas, they are more specific than the well-architected framework’s principles. B is a part of a principle, but data should be protected at rest and in transit. This leaves D, and people should be kept away from direct access to data. Instead, tools and APIs should provide a layer between users and data.

asking: The AWS’s well-architected framework defines five areas to consider with respect to secu-rity. Choose the two that are part of this set. (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: The five areas are Identity and Access Management (A), detective controls, infrastructure protection, data protection, and incident response (D).

asking: Who is responsible for physically securing the infrastructure that supports cloud services?

answerOption.description: AWS and you have joint responsibility.

rightAnswer.description: AWS takes responsibility for physically securing cloud infrastructure.

asking: Which of the following statements about the root account in an AWS account are true? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: It is the first account created.
It is ideal for everyday tasks.
It is intended primarily for creating other users and groups.
It has access keys that are important to keep.

rightAnswer.description: The root account is the first account in every account (A), but it should only be used for creating other users and groups (C). It is not intended for everyday tasks (B), and once account setup is complete, you are encouraged by AWS to delete any access keys (D).

asking: Which of the following are appropriate password policy requirements? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: A good password policy has minimum length and complexity requirements.

asking: What additional requirements should users that can access the AWS console have?

answerOption.description: Users with console access should have more stringent password policy requirements.
Users with console access should have to use their access keys to log in.
Users with console access should be required to use MFA.
None. These users should be treated the same as other users.

rightAnswer.description: Users with console access are more privileged users and should be required to use MFA (C). Password policies apply to all users, so A is incorrect. Further, passwords are the mechanism for logging into the console, so B is wrong in that access keys are not used for console login.

asking: Which of the following provide a means of federating users from an existing organiza-tion? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: SAML 2.0 and web identities both provide a means of working with an existing organizational identity provider.

asking: Which of the following principles suggests ensuring that authenticated identities are only permitted to perform the most minimal set of functions necessary?

rightAnswer.description: The principle of least privilege suggests that users only be allowed to do what they have to in order to perform their job functions.

asking: What is an AWS Organizations OU?

rightAnswer.description: AWS Organizations groups accounts into organizational units (OUs), allowing for groupings of permissions and roles.

asking: What is an AWS Organizations SCP?

rightAnswer.description: An SCP in AWS Organizations is a service control policy and can be applied to an organizational unit (OU) to affect all users within that OU. It effectively applies permissions at an organizational level, much the way that a group applies them at a user level.

asking: To which of the following constructs is an AWS Organizations SCP applied?

rightAnswer.description: Service control policies (SCPs) are applied to OUs (organizational units) in AWS Organizations.

asking: Which of the following can be used to centrally control AWS services across multiple AWS accounts?

rightAnswer.description: Service control policies (SCPs) provide for working across AWS accounts (A). Organizational units (OUs) are groupings of accounts, and IAM roles are applied to users and groups, not cross-account structures.

asking: What AWS service would you use for managing and enforcing policies for multiple AWS accounts?

rightAnswer.description: AWS Organizations offers a means of organizing and managing policies that span AWS accounts.

asking: Which of the following does AWS provide to increase privacy and control network access?

answerOption.description: Network firewalls built into Amazon VPC
Encryption in transit with TLS across all services
Connections that enable private and dedicated connections from an on-premises  environment

rightAnswer.description: AWS provides all of the above options as a means of providing security of the AWS environment.

asking: You have an application that uses S3 standard for storing large data. Your company wants to ensure that all data is encrypted at rest while avoiding adding work to your current development sprints. Which S3 encryption solution should you use?

rightAnswer.description: SSE-S3 offers encryption at rest while deferring key management to AWS. SSE-KMS does the same but has a higher cost and is more suitable for stringent auditing. The other two options involve work on the client side, which the question states is undesirable.

asking: You are the architect of an application that allows users to send private messages back and forth. You want to ensure encryption of the messages when stored in S3 and a strong auditing trail in case of a breach. You also want to capture any failed attempts to access data. What Amazon encryption solution would you use?

rightAnswer.description: SSE-KMS is the best solution for any encryption problem that requires a strong audit trail.

asking: Your company has just hired three new developers. They need immediate access to a suite of AWS services. What is the best approach to giving these developers access?

answerOption.description: Give the developers the admin credentials and change the admin password when they are finished for the day.
Create a new IAM user for each developer and assign the required permissions to each user.
Create a new IAM user for each developer, create a single group with the required permissions, and assign each user to that group.
Create a new SCP and assign the SCP to an OU with each user’s credentials within that OU.

rightAnswer.description: New users should be given a new IAM user, and when permissions are the same across users, a group should be used instead of individually assigning permissions.

asking: Your application requires a highly available storage solution. Further, the application will serve customers in the EU and must comply with EU privacy laws. What should you do to provide this storage?

answerOption.description: Create a new EC2 instance in EU-Central-1 and set up EBS volumes in a RAID con-figuration attached to that instance.
Create a new S3 standard bucket in EU-West-1.
Create a new Glacier vault in EU-South-1.
Create a new Auto Scaling group in EU-West-1 with at least three EC2 instances, each with an attached Provisioned IOPS EBS volume.

rightAnswer.description: Most of these answers are overly complicated. S3 is highly available by default, so simply setting up a bucket in an EU region is sufficient.

asking: Which of the following provides SSL for data in transit?

rightAnswer.description: All S3 storage classes provide SSL for data at transit as well as encryption of data at rest.

asking: Which of the following does not provide encryption of data at rest?

answerOption.description: All of these encrypt data at rest.

rightAnswer.description: All S3 storage classes provide SSL for data at transit as well as encryption of data at rest.

asking: What is the AWS shared responsibility model?

answerOption.description: A model that defines which components AWS secures and which you as an AWS cus-tomer must secure
A model that defines which components you secure and which components your cus-tomers must secure
A model that defines how connections between offices or on-premises data centers and the cloud must work together to secure data that moves between the two
A model that defines how the five pillars of the AWS well-architected framework interact

rightAnswer.description: The shared responsibility model defines the portions of the cloud that AWS secures, and the portions that you, the AWS customer, must secure.

asking: Which of the following is not one of the types of services that AWS offers, according to the shared responsibility model?

rightAnswer.description: This is pretty tough unless you’ve read the AWS shared responsibility white papers and FAQs. It’s really a matter of memorization and knowing that while AWS uses the term managed services in lots of areas, that term is not used in the shared responsibility model as one of the core types of services.

asking: For which of the following are you not responsible for security?

rightAnswer.description: AWS is responsible for the security of virtualization infrastructure. All other items in this list are your responsibility. As a hint on questions like this and related to the AWS shared responsibility model, AWS is typically responsible for anything with the word infrastructure, although there are some exclusions (for example, application infrastructure).

asking: Which of the following is used to allow EC2 instances to access S3 buckets?

rightAnswer.description: An IAM role is assumed by an EC2 instance when it needs to access other AWS services, and that role has permissions associated with it. While these permissions are formally defined in a policy (B), it is the role that is used by the instance for actual service access.

asking: You have a task within a Docker container deployed via AWS ECS. The application can-not access data stored in an S3 bucket. What might be the problem? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: The IAM role associated with the task doesn’t have permissions to access S3.
The task is not in a security group with inbound access allowed from S3.
The task does not have access to an S3 VPC endpoint.
There is no policy defined to allow ECS tasks to access S3.

rightAnswer.description: Just as is the case with a compute instance (EC2), a task in a container needs an IAM role with permissions to access S3 (A), which in turn requires a policy specifying a permission that lets ECS tasks access S3 (D). Both of these are required to ensure access. Security groups apply to network traffic and would not affect S3 access, and while a VPC endpoint could be used (C), it is not required.

asking: What is the default security on a newly created S3 bucket?

answerOption.description: Read and write is permitted from EC2 instances in the same region.
Completely private, reads and writes are disallowed.
There is no policy defined to allow ECS tasks to access S3.

rightAnswer.description: By default, newly created S3 buckets are private. They can only be accessed by a user that has been granted explicit access.

asking: You have a data analysis application that uses high compute instances along with RDS to do biological analysis on large datasets. The computations are not time sensitive and can be run anytime throughout the day. However, because of the high compute resources required, the processing is quite expensive. What could you do to defray these costs? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Purchase reserved instances and pay entirely up front for the instance usage charges.
Use the spot market, setting a bid price lower than the current on-demand pricing.
Lower the instance class to a less costly class and allow the processing to run longer at lower per-instance costs.
Contact AWS and ask for discounted instance pricing based on your recurring usage.

rightAnswer.description: When instance cost is the issue, the answers are almost always to consider some form of lowered instance pricing. AWS provides reserved instances and spot instances and the spot market for this purpose. Further, paying for reserved instances all up front is the most cost-effective means of getting reserved instances. Therefore, A and B are correct. C is problematic, as running a smaller instance for longer is not necessarily any cheaper than running a large instance for shorter amounts of time. Option D has some validity, but AWS is almost certainly going to point you back to either reserved instances or the spot market (A and B).

asking: Which of the following are valid payment options for reserved instances? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Reserved instances can be paid for in no up-front, partial up-front, and all up-front models, where all up-front is the least expensive and no up-front is the most expensive.

asking: How do you move a reserved instance from one region to another?

answerOption.description: Shut the instance down, change its region via the console or CLI, and restart the instance.
Contact your AWS billing resource to manually move the instance and its associated billing.
Make a snapshot of the instance, copy the snapshot to the new region, and start the instance from the snapshot.
You cannot move reserved instances across regions.

rightAnswer.description: Reserved instances are locked to the region in which they are created, so D is correct. You would need to create a new reserved instance in the new region.

asking: Which of the following allows you the least expensive access to compute resources?

rightAnswer.description: This should be an easy correct answer: Spot instances via the spot market are the potentially least expensive option, given that your compute has flexible timing and needs.

asking: Which of the following are not reasons to select an on-demand instance? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Applications that have flexible start and end times
Applications being developed or tested on EC2 for the first time

rightAnswer.description: Applications with spiky workloads are reasons to use on-demand, as on-demand can scale up and down quickly. Flexible start and end times is a criterion for choosing spot instances, and steady-state usage is ideal for reserved instances. Anytime you’re testing a new application, on-demand is a good choice

asking: Which of the following are reasons to select a spot instance? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Applications that have flexible start and end times
Applications that are only feasible at very low compute prices

rightAnswer.description: Applications with spiky workloads are reasons to use on-demand, as on-demand can scale up and down quickly. Flexible start and end times is a criterion for choosing spot instances, and steady-state usage is ideal for reserved instances. Spot instances also make heavy compute affordable when it would not be on other instance types.

asking: Which of the following are not reasons to select a reserved instance? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Applications that may require reserved capacity
Users with urgent computing needs for large amounts of additional capacity
Users that cannot make any up-front payment or long-term commitment

rightAnswer.description: The first option is easy, as it actually has reserved in the wording. Steady-state usage is also a use case for reserved instances, to gain cost savings. Large and immediate additional capacity needs are best facilitated by spot instances, and on-demand instances are best for users with no initial payment ability.

asking: Which of the following are reasons to select the S3 standard storage class? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Objects can easily be re-created if lost.

rightAnswer.description: S3 shares the durability of all S3 storage classes at 11 9s. It also provides the highest availability throughput of all S3 storage classes. Infrequent access is a use case for S3-IA, while the ability to re-create objects would suggest S3 One Zone-IA.

asking: You are the architect for a web application that exists on a cluster of EC2 instances all within an Auto Scaling group. During periods of high activity, the group scales up— adding instances—and then quickly scales back down. However, this occurs multiple times within a two-hour window, incurring significant costs. How could you reduce costs while ensuring that demand is still met? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Modify the Auto Scaling group’s cool-down timers.
Modify the Auto Scaling group to use scheduled scaling.
Lower the CloudWatch alarm threshold that causes the Auto Scaling group to scale up.
Modify the CloudWatch alarm period that causes the Auto Scaling group to scale down.

rightAnswer.description: The problem here is that instances are scaling down too quickly. This results in them then being restarted, which incurs cost. The solutions here should be ones that cause instances to stay around a bit longer, which meets demand. Both A and D do this. Cool-down timers increase the time for the group to ensure that previous scaling actions were completed (A), and the CloudWatch alarm period for scaling down should also be increased (D).

asking: Your company needs a storage solution that can support millions of customers accessing billing data. The data should be instantly accessible for users, but individual bills are not accessed that often. What is the most cost-efficient storage for this use case?

rightAnswer.description: This is a pretty “by the book” question, and in this case, is the exact use case for which S3-IA (Infrequent Access) was built. Instant access with less frequent requests is ideal for S3-IA.

asking: Is the S3-IA storage class less expensive than S3?

answerOption.description: It depends on how the storage class is used.

rightAnswer.description: S3-IA is less expensive than S3, regardless of use case. It is certainly possible that S3-IA is not appropriate for a certain use case, but it is less expensive on a “per byte retrieved” case.

asking: You have a website running on a fleet of EC2 instances behind an ELB. You also have an Auto Scaling group running across multiple availability zones. The instances are serving files from an EFS file system, but you are incurring lag and significant cost from serving these files from disk over and over. What would you recommend as a solution for reducing costs while still handling high traffic without degradation?

answerOption.description: Move the files into S3 standard.
Use Elastic Transcoder to reduce the file sizes.
Use reserved EC2 instances instead of on-demand instances.

rightAnswer.description: CloudFront will allow you to cache files that are frequently accessed. In this case, that should actually reduce costs. While CloudFront does incur a new additional cost, it would likely be offset by reduced egress from the EFS as well as the compute of additional EC2 instances to handle requests.

asking: You have a large archive of documents that must be backed up. The documents will be accessed very infrequently, if at all. However, when the documents are accessed, they must be delivered within 10 minutes of a retrieval request. What is the most cost-effective option for storing these documents?

rightAnswer.description: All the description here suggests using Glacier. The documents are a large archive, and many will never be accessed. However, the requirement for quick retrieval points to a need for expedited retrieval. Glacier with expedited retrieval is still going to cost less than S3-IA for access that isn’t that frequent.

asking: Your application has a 200 GB database running on an EC2 instance. You cannot move the database to RDS because of a custom spatial plug-in. The application is currently peaking in the morning and the evening, but the peaks are small and usage throughout the day is minimal. You need to ensure solid performance but keep costs low. What stor-age type would you use?

answerOption.description: EBS with a General Purpose SSD
EBS with a provisioned IOPS SSD

rightAnswer.description: First, EBS is a much better choice than EFS for a single-instance application. While a database would certainly benefit from IOPS, there’s no need; peaks are small, and usage overall is low. A General Purpose SSD is sufficient here.

asking: Which EBS volume type is most appropriate for use with a large database workload?

answerOption.description: EBS with a throughput optimized HDD
EBS with a General Purpose SSD
EBS with a provisioned IOPS SSD

rightAnswer.description: If you have a larger database workload, provisioned IOPS SSD is ideal.

asking: Which of the following is the least expensive EBS volume type?

rightAnswer.description: A cold HDD is the least expensive EBS volume type.

asking: Your application currently stores all its data on EBS volumes. You want to ensure that these volumes are backed up durably. However, you also want to use as few different  managed services as possible in order to keep backup costs low. What option would you recommend?

answerOption.description: Set up a Lambda function to take EBS snapshots and trigger the function through CloudWatch alarms.
Create a script to copy the EBS data to S3 and run it on an EC2 instance.
Mirror data across two EBS volumes.

rightAnswer.description: This is a tough question. You can eliminate B and C because both involve additional services: CloudWatch, Lambda, and additional EC2 instances. Taking EBS snapshots is good, and by moving those snapshots into S3 (which is the default), you get durability automatically. Mirroring data is also a great option—providing fault tolerance—but this does not provide a durability component, something the question specifically requires. Therefore, A is the best answer.

asking: You are the architect for a highly available and highly scalable accounting application. All transaction records in the application’s data stores must be available for immediate retrieval for three months, but then they should be purged to reduce storage costs. How can you most easily address this requirement?

answerOption.description: Store the transaction records on EBS and delete the volume after three months.
Store the transaction records in S3 and use lifecycle management to delete the records after three months.
Store the transaction records in Glacier and use lifecycle management to delete the records after three months.
Store the transaction records in EBS and use lifecycle management to delete the records after three months.

rightAnswer.description: There are two components to this question: which storage medium is appropriate,  and how should older records be deleted. To get both immediate retrieval and  lifecycle management, you’d need S3, as in option B. (Also, EBS does not offer lifecycle management, in option D.)

asking: You have heavy load on an RDS data instance. You want to avoid the overhead and cost of upgrading the instance to a larger instance size. What other options should you con-sider? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: RDS read replicas would take some of the read load off of the database instance, as would ElastiCache. The first allows reads to go to other instances, and the second caches already accessed data.

asking: You are in charge of storage for large datasets at a predictive analytics firm. You are tasked with minimizing storage costs. You need to store data 30–59 days old in a storage class that makes the data immediately available and data older than 60 days in a class that makes the data available within 10 hours. You want to use the least expensive classes available. Which two storage classes would you choose? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Glacier is the easy choice, as it can handle the oldest data and still meet the 10-hour retrieval time. S3 RRS is deprecated and shouldn’t be considered. This leaves S3 and S3-IA. S3-IA is always less expensive than S3, so it’s the better option here.

asking: You want to optimize performance and cost of your application by creating a placement group rather than hosting separate copies of your application in multiple availability zones. Across how many availability zones can a placement group span?

answerOption.description: Placement groups are not in availability zones.

rightAnswer.description: Placement groups are typically in a single availability zone, but now spread placement groups can be placed across availability zones.

asking: Across how many availability zones can a spread placement group be stretched?

answerOption.description: Placement groups are not in availability zones.

rightAnswer.description: It is typical to think of a spread placement group as a group spread across availability zones, but that is a misnomer. The spread in spread placement group means that the instances are spread across distinct underlying hardware, and although they can be spread across availability zones, they don’t have to be.

asking: How many instances can run in a single availability zone for a spread placement group?

rightAnswer.description: A spread placement group can have a maximum of seven running instances per AZ.

asking: Which of the following are advantages of a spread placement group over using non-grouped instances? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: A spread placement group can span peered VPCs in the same region.
A spread placement group is less expensive than the same number of on-demand instances not in a group.
A spread placement group allows instances to talk with negligible network lag.
A spread placement group reduces IO in an instance within that group.

rightAnswer.description: Spread placement groups primarily offer reduced network lag between instances (C). They also allow for cross-VPC spanning of instances (A).

asking: Which of the following statements about placement groups is false?

answerOption.description: A spread placement group can span peered VPCs in the same region.
A clustered placement group has instances all in a single availability zone.
A spread placement group allows instances to talk across regions without network lag.
A clustered placement group involves fewer availability zones than a spread placement group.

rightAnswer.description: The only false statement here is C: Spread placement groups cannot be set up across regions, and therefore this entire statement is untrue.

asking: Which of the following actions incur costs within AWS? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Transferring data from one instance to another within the same availability zone

rightAnswer.description: Egress always has a cost associated with it (B), while ingress is always free. Transferring data across regions is treated the same as transfers to the Internet. Only inter-AZ data transfer is guaranteed to be costless (D), making C the other correct answer.

asking: Which of the following costs the least?

answerOption.description: Retrieving a file from S3 to a local desktop client
An instance retrieving data from S3 in the same region
Uploading a file to S3 from a local desktop client
An instance retrieving data from S3 in a different region

rightAnswer.description: The least cost is always going to be “free,” so look for anything that might be ingress. In this cost, uploading to S3 is straight ingress and is therefore free and the cheapest option.

asking: Which of the following costs the least?

answerOption.description: Retrieving a file from S3 to a local desktop client
An instance retrieving data from another instance in the same availability zone
An instance storing data in S3 in a different region
An instance retrieving data from S3 in a different region

rightAnswer.description: There are no ingress options here, so nothing is guaranteed to be free. In that case, you should then look for something that moves data within the same availability zone. That’s always the least expensive (and usually free, depending on IP addresses), and in this case, that’s option B: inter-AZ data transfer between instances.

asking: Which of the following might help reduce data transfer costs? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Set up CloudFront to cache content.
Ensure that any instances communicating with other instances in the same region have private IP addresses.
Set up an RDS instance with read replicas.
Set up S3 buckets with versioning.

rightAnswer.description: First, CloudFront is always a good option. It’s free to move data from EC2 to CloudFront, so that could reduce how far data must travel, and associated costs. Then, private IPs allow for communication that doesn’t route out to the Internet, and generally AWS charges less for communication from private IP to private IP.

asking: Which of the following is not a level of AWS support?

rightAnswer.description: Although there is a free tier, it’s a billing option and not an actual support level. That makes B the non-level in this answer set.

asking: Which of the following is reduced as part of AWS’s total cost of ownership approach?

rightAnswer.description: AWS reduces the need for large capital expenditures and provides a pay-as-you-go model instead.

asking: Which of the following payment models does AWS employ to reduce total cost of ownership?

rightAnswer.description: AWS uses a pay-as-you-go model for all of its services.

asking: Which of the following is not a key tenet of the AWS pricing philosophy?

answerOption.description: Pay less per unit by using more.
Pay more only when AWS grows.

rightAnswer.description: D is incorrect; you actually pay even less as AWS grows, due to economies of scale.

asking: Which of the following is not a pricing model for instances?

rightAnswer.description: “Migration only” is not a pricing model for instances. The only model not mentioned here is dedicated hosts.

asking: When calculating total cost of ownership, what instance pricing model does AWS suggest using?

rightAnswer.description: AWS suggests using reserved instance pricing in TCO calculations, as it is closest to on-premises servers in an apples-to-apples comparison.

asking: How does the cost of standard reserved instances compare with the cost of on-demand instances?

answerOption.description: Standard reserved instances cost significantly less than on-demand instances.
Standard reserved instances cost about the same as on-demand instances.
Standard reserved instances cost significantly more than on-demand instances.
Standard reserved instances cost a little bit less than on-demand instances.

rightAnswer.description: Standard reserved instances often provide up to a 75% discount as compared to on-demand instances.

asking: Which of the following is not a valid payment option for reserved instances?

rightAnswer.description: There is no “half upfront” payment option. The valid options are no upfront, partial upfront, and all upfront.

asking: Which of the following is the least expensive payment model for reserved instances?

rightAnswer.description: Paying all upfront is the cheapest option of these three and provides the greatest savings over on-demand pricing.

asking: Which of the following are valid terms for reserved instances? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Reserved instances can be purchased for either one- or three-year terms.

asking: Which of the following are valid pricing models for EC2 instances? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: A spot instance (A) is a valid model, but spot market (B) is not; spot market is where you purchase spot instances. Dedicated hosts (C) is another valid model. All upfront is a payment option, but not an actual pricing model for instances.

asking: Which instance type is ideal for an application that has a flexible start and end time?

rightAnswer.description: Spot instances are recommended for applications with flexible start and end times, that need to run with low compute prices, or that may have urgent compute needs for large amounts of additional capacity.

asking: Which instance type is ideal for an application that suffers numerous spikes in usage at unpredictable times?

rightAnswer.description: On-demand instances are best when usage patterns swing severely and can’t be predicted.

asking: Which instance type is ideal for an application that has a long-running compute job that cannot be interrupted but also suffers from significant fluctuations in usage patterns?

rightAnswer.description: On-demand instances are ideal for any usage that swings wildly in unpredictable patterns, particularly if a job cannot be halted. If usage is predictable, a long-running job might benefit from a reserved instance, and if the job can be stopped, then spot instances would be better.

asking: Which of the following are valid ways to purchase dedicated hosts? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: This is a little tricky, as dedicated hosts function a bit differently than the other instance types, in both purchasing and payment. In this case, it’s important to note that the question is about purchasing, and not payment (which would drive you to answer “all upfront,” “partial upfront,” or “no upfront”). Dedicated hosts can be purchased as an on-demand instance or as a reservation for significant savings.

asking: Which of the following are reasons to consider reserved instances? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: You are running an application that involves lots of short-running compute jobs.
You are running an application with steady-state usage.
Your business is guaranteed to need cloud compute for at least the next 18 months.
You are looking to minimize commitments to AWS.

rightAnswer.description: Reserved instances are the best option for steady-state applications and require at least a one-year commitment, which would point to options B and C.

asking: Which of the following is not a reason to consider spot instances?

answerOption.description: Your applications have flexible start and end times.
Your applications can only run if compute costs are low because of CPU utilization.
You expect to have significant compute needs and potentially a need for lots of addi-tional capacity.
You expect usage to increase dramatically in the evenings and need to support that usage.

rightAnswer.description: Spot instances are not ideal for spikes in usage, as those instances may be terminated at any time.

asking: You have been brought in to introduce an organization to the cloud. They have several applications ideal for cloud hosting but do not want to make any up-front commitments. Further, they are concerned that the cloud will be “unreliable” so you need to ensure that applications run smoothly. What instance types would you recommend?

rightAnswer.description: In this scenario, you want to ensure that instances stay up (eliminating the spot market) and that there is no long-term commitment (eliminating reserved instances). Dedicated hosts don’t make sense, so this leaves on-demand instances.

asking: Which of the following are benefits to spot instances? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Applications can be paused and later resumed.
Costs are reduced compared to on-demand pricing.
The same hardware will be used for the life of an application.
They can handle spikes in usage without issue.

rightAnswer.description: The spot market provides instances that can stop and start at any time. Now, applications on these instances can be stopped and restarted (A). Additionally, costs are significantly lower than on-demand pricing (B). However, the hardware can change often, and spikes in usage are not well suited for spot instances.

asking: Which of the following offers the lowest pricing for storage (per GB)?

rightAnswer.description: On a pure “storage per GB” comparison, Amazon Glacier is the least expensive storage class.

asking: Which of the following is not an actual S3 storage class?

rightAnswer.description: S3-SSE is an encryption solution. Standard IA is infrequent access, RRS is reduced redundancy (and is now deprecated), and of course Glacier is a valid S3 storage class.

asking: Which of the following would not incur a charge?

answerOption.description: Distributing data via S3 signed URLs to an Internet client in the same region
Distributing data via CloudFront to an Internet client in a different region
Uploading data to S3 via a user’s web interface
Transferring data from an EC2 instance to an instance in another region

rightAnswer.description: Uploading data is the textbook definition of ingress, and ingress never has associated fees.

asking: Which of the following would not incur a charge?

answerOption.description: Transferring data from S3 to CloudFront
Distributing data via CloudFront to an Internet client in a different region
Transferring data from an EC2 instance to an instance in another region
Importing data to S3 via Transfer Acceleration

rightAnswer.description: It is always free to move data into CloudFront. There may be a cost associated with egress from CloudFront, but the transfer to CloudFront is cost-free.

asking: What is the AWS free tier?

answerOption.description: A platform for experimenting with AWS that can never be in production
A tier of AWS that allows limited access to AWS services at no cost
A class of EC2 instances that never cost anything for unlimited compute
A prepackaged suite of AWS services that can be used for web hosting at no cost

rightAnswer.description: The AWS free tier is just AWS but without a cost. You can use up to several limits of services (data transfer, compute, storage, etc.) at no cost within the AWS free tier.

asking: What is the AWS marketplace?

answerOption.description: A market for products, many of which can run on the AWS free tier
A market for prebuilt AMIs beyond the standard AWS offerings
A market for plug-ins and trials of paid third-party AWS services

rightAnswer.description: The AWS marketplace offers free and paid software products, many of which run on the AWS free tier. You can find AMIs and services as well as many trial offerings from third parties.

asking: What of the following services is available in AWS free tier?

rightAnswer.description: AWS free tier offers almost everything that paid AWS does, simply at lesser volumes.

asking: Which of the following is an AWS support plan?

rightAnswer.description: The four AWS support plans are basic, developer, business, and enterprise.

asking: Which of the following AWS support plans offer 24/7 support? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: This should be pretty intuitive: The higher and more business-oriented levels of support offer 24/7 support; in this case, business and enterprise.

asking: What is AWS Trusted Advisor?

answerOption.description: An online resource to help you reduce cost
A logging tool to help you detect intrusions
A performance tool to help you correctly size your Auto Scaling groups

rightAnswer.description: AWS Trusted Advisor is an online resource that helps you reduce cost as well as increase performance and improve security. However, it does not provide logging (C) or affect Auto Scaling limits or configuration.

asking: How many core Trusted Advisor checks does the Trusted Advisor tool provide?

rightAnswer.description: There are five core Trusted Adviser checks: cost optimization, security, fault tolerance, performance, and service limits. Note: In some places, AWS will say that there are seven checks, but in others, five. The most current documentation indicates the five checks noted here.

asking: Which of the following might be a recommendation from Trusted Advisor?  (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Turn on MFA for the root account.
Turn off global access to an S3 bucket.
Turn on Transfer Acceleration for S3.
Turn on MFA Delete for S3.

rightAnswer.description: AWS Trusted Advisor provides advice that typically is useful in all environments, for all use cases. In this set of answers, the two that meet that criteria are turning on MFA for the root account and avoiding global Internet access to an S3 bucket. These recommendations will apply to almost all situations. The other two options—C and  D—are use-case specific and therefore would not be suggested by Trusted Advisor.

asking: Which of the following is not an area in which Trusted Advisor makes recommendations?

rightAnswer.description: AWS Trusted Advisor makes recommendations about S3 bucket usage, IAM usage, and snapshots (both EBS and RDS) but does not make recommendations regarding DNS, so D is correct.

asking: Which of the following is not a category for which Trusted Advisor makes  recommendations?

rightAnswer.description: AWS Trusted Advisor makes recommendations in five categories: cost optimization, performance, security, fault tolerance, and service limits.

asking: Which of the following are categories for which Trusted Advisor makes recommenda-tions? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: AWS Trusted Advisor makes recommendations in five categories: cost optimization, performance, security, fault tolerance, and service limits.

asking: Which of the following might be an area about which Trusted Advisor makes recommen-dations? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: First, C is an easy choice: MFA on the root account is one of the most common recommendations. Then, consider the areas in which Trusted Advisor can make absolute recommendations; underuse of DNS records doesn’t make a lot of sense (how do you “underuse DNS?”) and coming up with the “correct” S3 storage class involves understanding use cases, which Trusted Advisor can’t do. This leaves A, idle load balancers.

asking: Which of the following are recommendations AWS makes to help you control your AWS costs? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Right-size your services to meet capacity at the lowest cost.
Buy high capacity and serve low capacity.

rightAnswer.description: AWS makes five standard recommendations: Right-size your services to meet capacity needs at the lowest cost, save money by reserving, use the spot market, monitor and track service usage, and use Cost Explorer to optimize savings.

asking: Which of the following might be a means by which you could decrease AWS costs in any standard application stack?

answerOption.description: Use Route 53 instead of non-AWS registrars.

rightAnswer.description: AWS makes five standard recommendations: Right-size your services to meet capacity needs at the lowest cost, save money by reserving, use the spot market, monitor and track service usage, and use Cost Explorer to optimize savings. Using the spot market (C) falls into that last category. The other answers are all use-case driven and really don’t fit into general cost-saving recommendations.

asking: What is AWS Cost Explorer?

answerOption.description: An analytics tool for evaluating instance usage
An analytics tool for evaluating RDS usage
An analytics tool for managing AWS costs over time
An analytics tool for managing application deployments

rightAnswer.description: This should be pretty basic: AWS Cost Explorer provides reports via analysis for evaluating your overall AWS costs over time.

asking: You want to anticipate your costs over the next year. Which of the following tools would you use?

rightAnswer.description: This is largely a matter of recognizing the valid AWS tools—AWS Trusted Advisor and AWS Cost Explorer—and then determining which deals with costs. In this case, that’s AWS Cost Explorer.

asking: You want to determine how your instance class choices are affecting your overall AWS spending. Which tool would help?

rightAnswer.description: Cost Explorer gives you reports on EC2 monthly cost and usage that can help analyze monthly spending on instances.

asking: You want to set limits on how much is spent monthly on S3 storage. Which of the follow-ing tools would be helpful?

rightAnswer.description: While AWS Cost Explorer can give you information about your monthly storage costs, AWS Budgets allows you to set alerts and then add custom programming to reduce or halt those costs.

asking: You want to cut off all access to your S3 buckets when a certain cost threshold is reached. Which tool allows you to do this?

rightAnswer.description: This is an important question. None of the tools listed allow for actual “cutoffs” at cost thresholds. AWS Budgets allows you notifications when a threshold is met but does not allow you to cut off spending at a certain point on its own.

asking: You need to produce media files optimized for various device types to optimize costs asso-ciated with transferring and viewing media on those devices. What AWS service would you use?

rightAnswer.description: Elastic Transcoder allows you to produce media files that are optimized and well suited for various device types.

asking: You want to reduce the maintenance costs of supporting Oracle on a fleet of EC2 instances. What service is well suited for offloading maintenance costs for Oracle data-base hosting?

rightAnswer.description: This question is as much about recognizing the various AWS service acronyms as anything. Here, RDS—the Relational Database Service—allows you to use Oracle on an AWS managed service.

asking: You want to delay the cost of hiring a large DevOps team while prototyping application hosting in the cloud. What service allows you to deploy your code with minimal  oversight?

rightAnswer.description: Elastic Beanstalk can deploy your code and handle capacity provisioning, load balancing, and setting up Auto Scaling and health checks, all with very little oversight. Note that you’d still need personnel to keep an application like this running, but Elastic Beanstalk can reduce initial resources needed for application deployment.

asking: You are tasked with reducing cost in an organization that does several new application deployments every week. The company has a common stack of resources but is spending time each deployment re-creating this stack. What would help you reduce initial setup and deployment costs?

rightAnswer.description: CloudFormation allows you to automate provisioning and, in this case, to create standardized JSON scripts that can be lightly modified to stand up entire stacks for multiple applications that share a common structure.

asking: You need to transfer 50 TB of data into S3 and want to avoid lengthy network exchanges and network saturation. What option would provide you with inexpensive data transfer at a large scale?

rightAnswer.description: Snowball is almost always the most cost-effective approach to data transfer when you approach 50 TB, and there are good reasons to consider it even at 10 TB or more.

asking: You want to take advantage of a large data store on premises that is already in use. How can you use this local storage while still interfacing with an additional cloud-based storage system and cloud-hosted EC2 instances?

rightAnswer.description: Storage Gateway is a hybrid storage service and allows your on-premises data store to interact with S3.

asking: You need to transfer several petabytes of data into AWS at the lowest possible costs. What AWS services could help?

rightAnswer.description: Large data should always make you think, “Snowball.” Snowball gives you a reliable, scalable, petabyte-scale data transfer solution.

asking: You need an analytics solution to perform business intelligence on your large data store. What AWS managed service can provide you with OLAP that reduces cost at scale?

answerOption.description: Oracle on an EC2 fleet with provisioned IOPS EBS volumes

rightAnswer.description: Redshift is AWS’s managed service for OLAP and business intelligence.

asking: You are currently running a fleet of 12 EC2 instances and processing large datasets that are uploaded by users. However, the cost of maintaining these instances is increasing, and the maintenance of the processing code is also growing. What AWS managed service would allow you to reduce these costs and still process large datasets?

rightAnswer.description: EMR, Elastic MapReduce, is a web service targeted at processing large amounts of data. It is optimized for this task and often provides cost savings over EC2 instances running similar processes.

asking: You are in charge of building a business intelligence application that can handle multiple data sources and perform analytics at a large scale. Which of the following services and tools would allow you to build a cost-effective solution? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: QuickSight is a business analytics service, and Redshift is ideal for business intelligence and OLAP. While you could build high-performance applications using EC2 instances and provisioned IOPS EBS volumes, managed services like QuickSight and Redshift are almost always going to be more cost effective.

asking: You have been tasked with combining several data sources into a single (optionally ephemeral) data store that you can then perform analysis on. You currently have data in RDS, two DynamoDB instances, and multiple S3 buckets. What is the most cost-effective approach to handling this task?

answerOption.description: A fleet of EC2 instances with throughput optimized SSD EBS volumes
A combination of CloudWatch, Lambda, and custom code

rightAnswer.description: Both A and B are going to incur significant costs and custom code. C is not a bad option on the analytics side but will still likely require custom code to aggregate the data sources. QuickSight, however, is designed exactly for this task: combining data sources and then performing analytics and extracting insights.

asking: Which of the following is the least expensive option for long-term data archival?

rightAnswer.description: Glacier is Amazon’s long-term data archival solution.

asking: Your company is paying a high cost for a consultant whose only job is the provisioning of resources for new cloud deployments. What AWS service would allow you to reduce this expenditure and move the consulting into more of a business-serving capacity?

rightAnswer.description: CloudFormation is ideal for automating deployment without manual intervention, but it’s actually Elastic Beanstalk that handles the provisioning of resources.

asking: You have been tasked with reducing the costs associated with a large fleet of EC2 instances that currently run several custom processes. These processes collect and collate data from a number of streaming data sources outside of your network. What AWS man-aged service could help replace these instances?

rightAnswer.description: Kinesis is intended to handle streaming data sources. It collects and processes data from these streaming sources in real time and would be ideal to replace custom code that handles this same process, as the question asks.

asking: You have been tasked with reducing the cost of a large group of EC2 instances that each serves a single process. The process is fired off when a user initiates it through a web interface. Because these processes are initiated often, a large fleet of EC2 instances is kept active to serve the requests, incurring significant monthly costs. What managed service could help you reduce the costs of these always-running instances?

rightAnswer.description: Lambda allows you to “ignore” the underlying resources required for running code. You simply give Lambda the code to run, and Lambda will handle provisioning resources in a scalable and cost-effective manner.

asking: You are in charge of a cloud migration from an on-premises data center to AWS. There are extensive software products used to monitor the on-premises applications, and you want to reduce the recurring costs associated with this monitoring. What AWS service would be ideal for this task?

rightAnswer.description: CloudWatch provides monitoring of applications and is a low-cost solution for AWS monitoring.

asking: You are in charge of a cloud migration from an on-premises data center to AWS. The sys-tem currently has a number of custom scripts that process system and application logs for auditing purposes. What AWS managed service could you use to replace these scripts and reduce the need for instances to run these custom processes?

rightAnswer.description: CloudTrail is the AWS service for logging and is particularly helpful for auditing and compliance.

asking: You are the architect in charge of designing a database-driven application suite. As part of the project, you need to migrate a large Oracle database instance into the cloud. Further, you are migrating from Oracle to PostgreSQL. How would you most effectively accom-plish this migration with the least expenditure?

answerOption.description: Copy the Oracle data to Snowball, send the data to AWS, move it into S3, and then import the data into PostgreSQL in RDS.
Create an RDS Oracle instance in AWS, migrate the data from the existing Oracle instance to the new RDS instance, and then convert the RDS instance to PostgreSQL.
Use the Database Migration Service to import the Oracle data directly into a new PostgreSQL instance.
Create a local PostgreSQL instance, migrate the data locally from Oracle to  PostgreSQL, and then move the PostgreSQL instance into AWS.

rightAnswer.description: Almost all of these add unnecessary steps and involve multiple instances or either Oracle or PostgreSQL. The easiest, most cost-effective option is to migrate directly from Oracle to PostgreSQL using DMS, the Database Migration Service.

asking: You need to choose a scalable, cost-effective, and highly durable solution for storing flat files. What AWS service would you use?

rightAnswer.description: S3 is the AWS choice for durability and flat-file (non-relational data) storage.

asking: You have been tasked with replacing a legacy LDAP directory server that manages users, groups, and permissions with a cloud-based solution in order to reduce maintenance costs for the current directory server. What AWS service should you investigate?

rightAnswer.description: IAM is the best option for handling users, groups, and permissions within AWS.

asking: You have been tasked with replacing a legacy LDAP directory server that manages users, groups, and permissions and provides single sign-on capabilities with a cloud-based solu-tion in order to reduce maintenance costs for the current directory server and codebase. What AWS services should you investigate? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: IAM is the best option for handling users, groups, and permissions within AWS. You can then add Cognito to offer single sign-on capabilities to your applications.

asking: You are new on a project that makes heavy use of AWS. Your first priority is to reduce costs and identify security risks. What tool could you use to scan the existing environment and set initial priorities for change?

rightAnswer.description: Trusted Advisor is a great start to find glaring holes or deficiencies in an AWS environment.

asking: You are migrating a large on-premises application suite to AWS. Your company has made a significant investment in Chef for configuration and management and doesn’t want to lose the investment in time and money that the Chef tool represents. How could you pre-serve this functionality and keep costs low?

rightAnswer.description: OpsWorks is a configuration management tool that actually can use Chef, so many of the existing modules would plug right in and existing expertise would translate directly over.

asking: How many times will a message be delivered when using a standard SQS queue?

answerOption.description: Once for each request of the relevant message in the queue

rightAnswer.description: AWS does guarantee that all SQS messages will be delivered at least once, but the message may be delivered more than once (making option A incorrect). This is not related to the number of requests to the queue or the applications using the queue; therefore, both C and D are incorrect. This leaves B, the correct answer.

asking: Which of the following services allow you to access the underlying operating system? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: This is a common question AWS often asks to ensure that you understand that managed services like RDS and DynamoDB are indeed completely managed: You cannot access the underlying operating system of the service. This leaves EC2 and EMR as the remaining, and correct, answers. While EMR does provide you with a lot of functionality “out of the box,” it still allows root level access, as do EC2 instances.

asking: You are using an SQS queue in your web application. You are able to confirm that mes-sages in the queue are being picked up by application instances for processing, but then nothing happens for over 12 hours. Then, after that period of time, the message appears in the queue again and processing restarts. What could be occurring?

answerOption.description: The SQS queue has a visibility timeout that is set too high. The timeout should be reduced so that application instances can process the message more quickly.
SQS messages expire every 12 hours and must be reentered into the queue. The time that the message is invisible triggers the queue to ask for and receive the message from the original sender.

Processing is failing, or not completing, in the application instance. The message dis-appears because the SQS queue keeps it “invisible” for 12 hours while it is being pro-cessed. The message is then returned to the queue for processing if not handled prior to that timeout.
Your SQS queue needs to be restarted; it is likely not correctly queuing messages. The polling interval is also set too high, causing the long lack of visibility of the message.

rightAnswer.description: SQS queues have a visibility timeout that controls how long a message in the queue is marked as “invisible” while being processed. This accounts for the message “disappearing.” Then, if application processing fails—as in option C—the message is remarked as visible and is available for processing again. Option A correctly notes this timeout, but reducing the timeout would not cause the message to be processed correctly. It would just reduce the time that the message is “invisible.” Option B is not how queues work; they cannot ask a sender to resend a message. Option D is incorrect as well, as the queue is operating as intended with regard to visibility of messages and timeouts.

asking: Which of the following is a valid method of performing actions on an EBS snapshot?

answerOption.description: Use the AWS console with a username and password.
Use the AWS CLI with an application key.
Use the AWS REST APIs with an application key.

rightAnswer.description: Snapshots are accessible through the console via username/password and through AWS CLI and APIs via application key.

asking: Which of the following is most like a mailing list?

rightAnswer.description: SNS is the Simple Notification Service and functions like a mailer, sending out notifications that can be subscribed to by other applications.

asking: In which of the following managed services are messages not pushed?

rightAnswer.description: SNS sends out notifications to subscribed listeners, and SWF pushes out messages as they arrive. Only SQS holds messages until the queue is polled. Redshift is not a messaging service at all but rather a data warehousing solution.

asking: In which of the following managed services can messages be pulled by an application?

rightAnswer.description: SNS and SWF operate on a push approach. SQS holds messages until they are pulled out of the queue. S3 is not a message store.

asking: Which of the following managed services guarantees single assignment of a message?

rightAnswer.description: Both SWF and SQS deliver a message at least once, but only SWF guarantees that a message will only be delivered a single time.

asking: Which of the following managed services calls the messages it receives tasks?

rightAnswer.description: Messages in SWF are tasks; messages in SQS are messages; messages in SNS are notifications. S3 is a storage solution, not a messaging solution.

asking: Which of the following managed services calls the messages it receives notifications?

rightAnswer.description: Messages in SWF are tasks; messages in SQS are messages; messages in SNS are notifications. S3 is not a messaging solution at all.

asking: Which of the following managed services calls the messages it receives “messages”?

rightAnswer.description: Messages in SWF are tasks; messages in SQS are messages; messages in SNS are notifications. S3 is not a message store. Since SQS is not an option, the answer is D, none of these.

asking: Which of the following managed services coordinates activities between different  applications?

rightAnswer.description: SWF is more than a simple queue. It automates workflow, moving a task (what SWF calls its messages) from one application component to the next in a predetermined order.

asking: What does SWF stand for?

rightAnswer.description: SWF is not exactly a true acronym. It stands for Simple Workflow Service but is not represented by SWS. Instead, the WF refers to workflow.

asking: What services are suitable for running compute-intensive custom scripts? (Choose two.)

rightAnswer.description: Both EC2 and ECS provide environments on which your custom code can run, and both are compute services. S3 is a storage service, and Redshift is a data warehousing solution. While Redshift can be helpful in analysis of data, it is not suitable for running custom scripts.

asking: Which AWS service is ideal for hosting a website while requiring the least amount of AWS staff and knowledge?

rightAnswer.description: Of the choices available, Amazon Lightsail is the easiest solution for getting simple applications running quickly. EC2 and ECS are both much more complex. While S3 website hosting is a web hosting solution, it does require quite a bit of AWS knowledge (security, permissions, etc.).

asking: You have a registered AMI using an EBS volume as a root device, created from a volume snapshot. However, you have detected malicious code running in the EBS volume and want to remove the AMI and delete the EBS volume and its snapshot. What steps are required? (Choose two.)

answerOption.description: Immediately delete the EBS volume snapshot.
After the EBS volume has been deleted, deregister the AMI.
After the AMI has been deregistered, remove the AMI, and delete the EBS volume and its snapshot.

rightAnswer.description: An EBS snapshot cannot be deleted if it is the root device of a registered AMI while that AMI is in use. You’ll need to deregister the AMI first (B), and then you can delete the EBS volume and any snapshots and stop using the AMI.

asking: Which of the following AWS CLI commands is used to operate upon EBS volumes?

answerOption.description: You cannot operate upon EBS volumes directly from the AWS CLI.

rightAnswer.description: EBS is considered a subset of EC2 functionality. Therefore, you use the aws ec2 commands; for example, aws ec2 delete-snapshot.

asking: You have a website running at applestoapples.net. However, many of your users have  mistakenly entered in applestoapples.com as the URL in their browser. To correct this, you’ve recently purchased the additional domain applestoapples.com and now want to point all requests to this domain to applestoapples.net. Which DNS record set would you use?

rightAnswer.description: A records are used to point a specific domain or subdomain to an IP address. CNAMEs point to a different URL, which in turn can be resolved further by DNS. In this case, you’d want to create a CNAME record for applestoapples.com and point that record to applestoapples.net and then let DNS resolve that domain. Using an A record means you’d have to lock the record to a specific IP rather than the domain name for applestoapples.net. That’s a problem, though, as over time, the domain may be served by different resources with different IP addresses, making the A record dated and incorrect.

asking: Your website has mostly static content, but you are adding a new section driven by an EC2 instance fleet behind an Elastic Load Balancer. You want to create a subdomain and direct all traffic to that subdomain toward the ELB. Which DNS record set would you use?

rightAnswer.description: A records are used to point a specific domain or subdomain to an IP address. CNAMEs point to URLs or other domain names. In this case, since you’re pointing at an ELB, you’d need to use a CNAME, as ELBs don’t expose a public IP address.
